newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: South Europeans face long road to EMU - Austria.
newsitem.headline: South Europeans face long road to EMU - Austria.

text.p: Economic and monetary union (EMU) was likely to start on schedule with seven or eight member countries, Austrian central bank director Adolf Wala said on Tuesday.

Wala declined to specify which particular countries he saw among the first to joint a single currency or whether any of the European Union's southern member states, such as Italy, Spain or Portugal, would be able to participate early.
"There's a chance, but they face a much longer road," Wala was quoted as saying by Austrian news agency APA.
"The efforts of these countries (to qualify for EMU) have to be taken seriously. It has to be made clear that they will be part of EMU -- even if only at a later stage," he added.

Italy has presented a stringent 1997 budget to try meet the strict criteria for EMU membership, but several officials at Germany's Bundesbank have recently cast doubt on whether Italy will be able to qualify in time.
